MUET 200

Library resources useful in completing assignments for MUET 200--World Popular Musics and Identity.
  • Home
  • WorldCat UMD (books, media, articles)
  • RILM (scholarly articles, dissertations)
  • Music Index (magazines, scholarly articles)
  • I'm Stuck

Subject Guide

Steve Henry

Subjects:Dance, Ethnomusicology, International Piano Archives, Music, Music Education, Piano Music, Popular Music, Special Collections in Performing Arts, Theatre

Inroduction

This guide is designed to help you use the library to locate scholarly and reputable sources to support your papers on identity and world popular music. For simplicity's sake, I will focus on four main library resources: WorldCat UMD, the RILM database, and Music Index. You can use the tabs above to learn more about these tools. As a summary:

  • WorldCat UMD is probably the best place to start. It will find books (paper and e-books) available from the library, recordings, DVDs (including documentaries), and much more. It will also return a smattering of scholarly articles, but to find many more, try using RILM. Click the WorldCat UMD tab above for more hints and information.
     
  • RILM is another great resource to know. It indexes scholarly articles, books on music, dissertations, some popular music magazines, and more, and is definitely the best tool for finding scholarly articles. Since RILM does skew a little bit toward the scholarly side, you won't always find articles on the most current popular music acts (for those, try finding magazine articles from Music Index). Although RILM includes many articles in full-text, it is not a completely full-text database. You may need to take additional steps to locate an article in the library once you've identified it. See the RILM tab on this guide for more information.
     
  • Music Index is very similar to RILM in that it is an index to literature on music. However, Music Index tends to cover more popular music magazines (like Spin Magazine, or Rolling Stone, etc.). So Music Index is a good place to check for non-scholarly but reputable sources. You'll notice that Music Index and RILM look almost identical (because they're provided by the same database vendor). This is good because once you've learned one, you'll know how the other works. In fact, you can search both databases simultaneously by clicking Choose Databases and add both to your search. More information is available on the Music Index tab.

For many topics related to this course, those three will suffice. However, depending on your topic, there may be other tools that will be helpful. If you are stuck, check out the I'm Stuck tab of the guide for some suggestions. If you have questions or would like further guidance, please contact me. My profile with contact info appears on every page of this guide and you can contact me however you like.
